data.title: Manhattan Project
data.meta_description: Read more about Manhattan Project from The New Yorker
data.text:
The Front Row

“Oppenheimer” Is Ultimately a History Channel Movie with Fancy Editing

Christopher Nolan’s bio-pic is so intent on being a morality tale that it misses its protagonist’s complexity.

The Political Scene Podcast

Adapting Oppenheimer’s Life Story to Film, with the Biographer Kai Bird

Bird’s Pulitzer Prize-winning biography was the foundation for Christopher Nolan’s movie “Oppenheimer,” an epic about the father of the atomic bomb.

News Desk

Why Scientists Become Spies

Access to information only goes so far to explain the curious link between secrets and those who tell them.

Annals of Technology

Remembering the Chicago Pile, the World’s First Nuclear Reactor

Seventy-five years ago, in the heart of America’s second-largest city, a group of scientists lit a secret fire.

Annals of Technology

America at the Atomic Crossroads

Seventy years ago, at Bikini Atoll, weapons of mass destruction became a form of consumer entertainment.

Annals of Technology

The Light of Trinity, the World’s First Nuclear Bomb

In 1945, the flash of the first-ever nuclear explosion illuminated the skies over the New Mexico desert.

A Reporter at Large

Break-In at Y-12

Double Take
